Theoretical & Computational Chemistry at the University of Pittsburgh

The University of Pittsburgh has one of the largest groups of researchers engaged in Theoretical & Computational Chemistry research of any U. S. academic institution.

    News

  • Dec 31, 2999 - 2016 Midwest Theoretical Chemistry Conference to Be Held at Pitt
  • Oct 16, 2015 - Prof. Lambrecht Receives $110k Grant from ACS PRF
  • Oct 29, 2015 - Annual Symposium on Research Computing to Be Held on Oct 29
  • Apr 23, 2016 - Pittsburgh Quantum Institute Symposium to Be Held April 20 - 22, 2016

Other Groups Engaged in Computational Chemistry on Campus

The Chemical and Petroleum Engineering Department has five groups (Anna Balazs, John Keith, Yanni Mpourmpakis, Karl Johnson, and Chris Wilmer) engaged in computational chemistry research and the Department of Computational and Systems Biology in the Medical School also has groups (Ivet Bahar, Daniel Zuckerman) part of whose research has a significant computational chemistry component.

There are also several Theoretical & Computational Chemistry groups at Pittsburgh’s two other major universities – Carnegie Mellon University and Duquesne University – as well as at the DOE National Energy Technology Laboratory (NETL) just outside the city.

Computational Resources

The University of Pittsburgh’s Center for Simulation and Modeling (SaM) houses an ~7,500 CPU core cluster with high-speed Infiniband connectivity for running demanding highly parallel calculations. Several of the nodes have GPU co-processors. SaM also has a team of Ph.D.-level consultants who assist researchers with improving performance of their codes and teach workshops on various aspects of scientific computing. Pittsburgh also hosts the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC), an NSF-funded National Center. PSC hosts a 512-node Anton special-purpose machine with support from NIH. PSC holds multiple workshops on various aspects of computing each year. These have proven quite valuable to our students.
